Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Sizing Up the Smoke--Evaluating and Improving Our Ability to Predict Aged Wildfire Aerosol Size Distributions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is focused on studying the aging of emissions from biomass burning. Small particles emitted from biomass combustion can react in the atmosphere, changing their size, number, and composition. These aging processes will be modeled and the model results will be tested against actual data from field campaigns.

The following questions will be investigated: (1) What are the chemical processes that, when combined with the dispersion and coagulation of biomass-burning emissions, capture the evolution of aerosol size and number concentrations seen in the laboratory and the field? (2) Are the secondary organic aerosol (SOA) formation rates and size-distribution changes measured in lab experiments consistent with the field measurements of aerosol aging? If they are not, can we determine why (e.g. lack of continuous dilution or wall losses in chamber experiments)? (3) What properties most strongly determine the aged biomass-burning aerosol size and number? E.g. total mass emission flux, fresh particle size, fuel type, modified combustion efficiency, wind speed, fire area, vertical mixing depth, sunlight. (4) Can the variability in aged biomass-burning aerosol size and number be captured by a simple parameterization that is a function of the most important of the above properties?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Wildfires are a major source of particles (aerosols) to the atmosphere. These particles impact air quality and human health, and they also impact climate by scattering and absorbing sunlight. The magnitude of the climate impacts, however, have remained uncertain. These climate impacts depend on the concentration, size, and composition of particles. These particle properties have been observed to evolve rapidly through chemistry and physics in the atmosphere, but the properties vary between smoke plumes, and these properties are not well captured in climate models.

This project sought to understand the evolution of the climate-relevant properties of smoke particles by developing new modelling tools, analyzing laboratory and field experiments of smoke, building smoke-evolution schemes for climate models, and testing these schemes in climate models. Highlights from this project include: (1) Development of a new modelling tool, SAM-ASP, which spatially resolves diluting smoke plumes and explicitly simulates the chemistry and physics in the plume. (2) Theoretical analysis of the role of plume dilution on the chemical/physical evolution of plume particles. (3) Analysis of ambient smoke-plume observations to test/confirm this role of dilution. (4) A critical-review paper addressing the observed chemical evolution of smoke in laboratory and field data, which addresses discrepancies between datasets. (5) Determination of the key gaseous vapors that add to smoke particles upon chemical reactions, using laboratory data. (6) Development of a scheme to represent in-plume particle coagulation for climate models. (7) Implementation of this in-plume coagulation scheme in a climate model to assess the changes in smoke-climate effects. (8) Building a climatology of observed climate-relevant smoke properties in different regions of the US.

 

Broader impacts

Wildfire burn area has been observed to increase in the US in recent decades, which has increased the emissions of smoke particles, impacting air quality and climate. At the same time, emissions of human-generated particles from power plants and transportation have been decreasing, making wildfires the main source of particles in many regions of the US. Wildfire burn area has been predicted to continue to increase in the future due to projected climate changes. As smoke particles tend to cool climate, smoke may provide a negative feedback to future warming, where warming creates more fires, which emit smoke that cools the planet. This smoke-climate feedback has not been well studied and requires precise knowledge of the climate-relevant smoke properties, which this project helped elucidate.

This project funded the research of one masters student in the Department of Atmospheric Science at Colorado State University, and it funded one early career scientist in this department at Colorado State and two early career scientists at Atmospheric and Environmental Research. Through this project, these young scientists gained skills in analysis and mathematical modelling of the chemistry and physics of particles in the atmosphere, skills that translate to a wide range of jobs in science and engineering.
